Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mechanstic Studies Involving Late Transition Metal Complexes for Catalytic Carbon Dioxide Conversion
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CAREER award funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Nilay Hazari of the Department of Chemistry at Yale University will develop transition metal catalysts for the conversion of carbon dioxide into organic building blocks. In particular monomeric Ni and Pd complexes that promote the formation of new C-C bonds from carbon dioxide will be targeted. This could result in the development of a functional group tolerant catalyst that can convert carbon dioxide into carboxylic acids, which are highly useful in synthetic chemistry. The broader impacts of this program include the development of a program that will encourage local high school students to visit different research laboratories at Yale.

The catalytic conversion of carbon dioxide into more valuable compounds is an important problem due to the potential of this greenhouse gas as a readily available and inexpensive source of carbon in the construction of more complex molecules. Currently, there are relatively few practical methods for converting carbon dioxide into useful chemicals and the development of new catalysts for carbon dioxide conversion could have important impact on sustainable chemistry. In this work carboxylic acids which are present in many organic compounds will be synthesized from carbon dioxide. In addition, alongside the training of both undergraduate and graduate students, a program will be introduced which allows local high school students to visit chemistry laboratories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long term goal of this project was to develop new catalytic systems for the conversion of carbon dioxide into more valuable molecules. The approach to achieving this goal involved fundamental experimental and computational studies exploring the reactivity of transition metal compounds with carbon dioxide. The award resulted in twelve peer-reviewed publications with the PI as the lead author. These include multiple articles in high impact journals such as The Journal of the American Chemical Society, Angewandte Chemie International Edition, and Chemical Science. Furthermore, an invited review article on carbon dioxide insertion was also written.

The research performed as part of this award can be separated into three themes as summarized below.

i) Understanding carbon dioxide insertion into late transition metal complexes

The insertion of carbon dioxide into late transition metal-element sigma bonds is relevant to many catalytic cycles for carbon dioxide conversion into value-added chemicals. Carbon dioxide insertion into Group 10 alkyl, allyl, alkynyl, hydrido, hydroxido, amido, oxazolido, and imidazolido bonds was studied. DFT calculations show that in most cases, these reactions proceed through a rate-determining transition state (TS) in which there is no interaction between carbon dioxide and the metal, which is often referred to as an outersphere process. In our studies, it was demonstrated that one of the only major classes of complexes that do not insert carbon dioxide via an outersphere pathway is pincer-supported Group 10 hydrides, where carbon dioxide insertion occurs via a rate-determining TS featuring an interaction between the metal and an oxygen atom of carbon dioxide. Regardless of the insertion mechanism, it was demonstrated that the presence of a strong trans-influence ligand opposite the metal-element sigma-bond undergoing insertion reduces the kinetic barrier and increases the thermodynamic driving force for insertion.

 

ii) Fundamental studies of the structure and bonding in Group 10 pincer complexes

Pincer ligands are ubiquitous in coordination chemistry due to their ability to stabilize reactive transition metal complexes and generate species with high thermal stability. Although research focused on reactivity studies, insight was also gained into the structure and bonding of Group 10 pincer compounds. Most notably it was shown that a four-center two-electron (4c-2e) bond between two metal centers and two bridging ligands containing silicon atoms stabilizes hypervalent silicon atoms and that nickel(0) complexes containing dinitrogen ligands could be prepared.

 

iii) Studies on the synthesis and properties of palladium(I) and nickel(I) complexes

The chemistry of palladium(I) and nickel(I) complexes is less well-studied than species in the palladium(0)/nickel(0) and palladium(II)/nickel(II) oxidation states. As part of this project new syntheses for palladium(I) species containing bridging allyl, cyclopentadienyl, or indenyl ligands were developed and the properties of these complexes elucidated. Additionally, to probe the formation of nickel(I) complexes in catalysis, the role of nickel(I) species in Suzuki-Miyaura coupling (SMC) reactions was studied. In SMC reactions involving aryl chlorides, it was demonstrated that nickel precatalysts form a catalytically active nickel(I) species, which is the predominant species at the end of the reaction, regardless of the starting oxidation state of the precatalyst. This work was extended to less reactive aryl sulfamate electrophiles, where it was shown that the nickel(I) species formed during catalysis were off-cycle complexes. These results were used to find more active NiII catalysts for SMC reactions involving both aryl chlorides and sulfamates.

 

The scientific broader impacts from this award relate to the generation of fundamental information for the design of improved catalysts for carbon dioxide conversion and nickel catalyzed cross-coupling. In the case of nickel catalyzed cross-coupling, the PI has an active collaboration with a major pharmaceutical company, to assist in commercializing this work. Alongside these scientific efforts, graduate students were trained in organometallic chemistry and an outreach event in the Yale Chemistry Department was started as part of Yale’s Pathways to Science Program. Pathways is an initiative that coordinates all of Yale’s pre-college STEM outreach with the goal of encouraging local students to study in STEM areas in college and to pursue STEM-based careers. The event that was created is known as ‘Pathways Chemistry Open House’. In this event, Pathways students and their families visit departmental research laboratories, discuss science with both faculty and graduate students, and observe demonstrations. The goal of the day is to inspire students to pursue a career in science and help underrepresented groups explore the many different areas of chemistry. Over the last 5 years, more than 70 members of the Chemistry Department have participated, and more than 500 students and their parents have visited the department. At the end of the day, Pathways has conducted a written evaluation of the event, and the feedback has been highly positive. Additionally, this event provides an opportunity for graduate student to develop their skills communicating with a general audience.
